entry.title: xv6 book ç¬”è®°
entry.content:
xv6 book

======

chapter 2

operating system organization

There are three key requirements must fulfilledï¼šmultiplexing, isolation, and interaction.

This chapter will demonstrate above three requirements by providing an overview of xv6â€™s process (unit of isolation) and the creation of the first process when xv6 starts.

XV6 is written in â€˜LP64â€™C, which means long (L) and pointers (P) in the C programming language are 64 bits, but an int is 32 bits.

2.1 abstracting physical resources

Abstracting physical resources is very necessary.

2.2 User mode, supervisor mode, and system calls

Operating system need strong isolationï¼Œit means os or other applications canâ€™t fail when a application makes a mistake.Instead,the os should be able to clean up the failed application and continue running other applications.Therefore, applications canâ€™t modify osâ€™data, instructions and access other applicationsâ€™ memory.

CPUs have some support for strong isolation. For example, RISC-V has three modes in which the CPU can execute instructions: machine mode, supervisor mode, and user mode.

machine mode:     - have full privilege;    - a CPU starts in machine mode;    - mostly intended for setting up the computer during boot;supervisor mode:    - the CPU is allowed to execute privileged instructions(ç‰¹æƒæŒ‡ä»¤);    - if an app in user mode attempts to execute a privileged instructions,CPU     doesn't execute the instruction,but switches to supervisor mode so that     supervisor-mode code can terminate the application, because it did     something it shouldnâ€™t be doing;    - some app running in supervisor mode(also can execute privileged     instructions)said to be running in kernel space is called the kernel;user mode:    - An application can execute only user-mode instructions and is said to be     running in user space;    - an application in user mode cannot invoke a kernel function directly;

An application cannot invoke a kernel function directly.
CPUs provide a special instruction(â€˜ecallâ€™ in RISC-V) that switches the CPU from user mode to supervisor mode(and enters the kernel).

Once the CPU has switched to supervisor mode, the kernel can then validate the arguments of the system call (e.g., check if the address passed to the system call is part of the applicationâ€™s memory), decide whether the application is allowed to perform the requested operation (e.g., check if the application is allowed to write the specified file), and then deny it or execute it. It is important that the kernel control the entry point for transitions to supervisor mode.if the application could decide the kernel entry point, a malicious application could enter the kernel at a point where the validation of arguments is skipped.

2.3 Kernel organization

CPUs have three running modeï¼Œthen it was a question that which part of OS should run in supervisor mode. There are two options to chooseï¼šentire operating system resides in the kernel (monolithic kernel) or part of the operating system is in the kernel, and the rest is on the outside(microkernel). xv6 is monolithic.

monolithic kernelï¼š    Propertyï¼š    - the entire operating system consists of a single program running with     full hardware privilege.    - is convenient for OS designer.    - is easier for different part of OS to cooperate.    Downsideï¼š    - interactions in the OS are often complex.    - fatalï¼a litle error could cause the kernel to fail and the computer     stops working, and thus all applications fail too.microkernel:    Propertyï¼š    - minimize the amount of operating system code that runs in supervisor     mode.    - execute the bulk of the operating system in user mode.    - OS services running as processes in user mode are called servers(such as     File server).    - kernel provides a an inter-process communication mechanism for user-mode     processes.    - the kernel interface consists of a few low-level functions for starting     applications, sending messages, accessing device hardware, etc.

2.4 Code: xv6 organization

  • The xv6 kernel source is in the kernel/sub-directory.

  • The source is divided into files, following a rough notion of modularity.

  • The inter-module interfaces are defined in defs.h (kernel/defs.h).

2.5 Process overview

The unit of isolation in OS is a process. One process canâ€™t wrecking or spying on another processâ€™s(of course include kernel itself) memory, CPU, file descriptors, etc. The mechanisms used by the kernel to implement processes include the user/supervisor mode flag, address spaces, and time-slicing of threads.

Xv6 uses page tables (which are implemented by hardware) to give each process its own address space. The RISC-V page table translates (or â€œmapsâ€) a virtual address (the address that an RISC-V instruction manipulates) to a physical address (an address that the CPU sends to main memory).

Each process have own page table. Page tables defines processâ€™s address space.
An address space includes the processâ€™s user memory starting at virtual address zero.

  • Instructions come first,
  • followed by global variables,
  • then the stack,
  • and finally a â€œheapâ€ area (for malloc) that the process can expand as needed.
  • the trampoline page(4096 bytes) contains the code to transition in and out of the kernel,
  • the trapframe is where the kernel saves the processâ€™s user registers,

Some factors limit the maximum size of a processâ€™s address space:

  • pointers on the RISC-V are 64 bits wide;
  • the hardware uses only the low 39 bits when looking up virtual addresses in page tables;
  • and xv6 uses only 38 of those 39 bits.
  • Thus, the maximum address is 238 âˆ’ 1 = 0x3fffffffff, which 26 is MAXVA (kernel/riscv.h:378).

struct â€œprocâ€

The xv6 kernel gathers many pieces of state for each process into a struct proc(kernel/proc.h:85). Most important state are page tables, kernel stack and run state. Use the notation p->xxx to refer to elements of the proc structure.

p->state:
indicates whether the process is allocated, ready to run, currently running on a CPU, waiting for I/O, or exiting.

p->pagetable:
holds the processâ€™s page table, A processâ€™s page table also serves as the record of the addresses of the physical pages allocated to store the processâ€™s memory.

thread

Each process has a thread of control. The thread holds the state needed to execute the process.
A thread either executing on a CPU, or suspended(capable of resuming executing in the feture).
When CPU will switch to another process, the kernel:

  1. suspends the running thread
  2. saves running threadâ€™s state
  3. restores the state of another processâ€™s previously-suspended thread

stacks

Much of the state(local variables, function call return addresses) is stored on the threadâ€™s stcaks. Each process has two stacks: a user stack and a kernel stack (p->kstack).
When the process is executing user instructions, only its user stack is in use, and its kernel stack is empty.When the process enters the kernel (for a system call or interrupt), the kernel code executes on the processâ€™s kernel stack.
The kernel stack is separate (and protected from user code) so that the kernel can execute even if a process has wrecked its user stack.

come and go kernel

A process can make a system call by executing the RISC-V ecall instruction.
ecall instruction:

  • This instruction raises the hardware privilege level
  • changes the program counter to a kernel-defined entry point
  • The code at the entry point switches to kernel stack and executes the kernel instructions that implement the system call.

When the system call completes, the kernel switches back to the user stack and returns to user space by calling the sret instruction.
sret instruction:

  • lowers the hardware privilege level
  • resumes executing user instructions just after the system call instruction

A processâ€™s thread can â€œblockâ€ in the kernel to wait for I/O, and resume where it left off when the I/O has finished.

**In summary, a process bundles two design ideas: an address space to give a process the illusion of its own memory, and a thread to give the process the illusion of its own CPU.

2.6 Code: starting xv6, the first process and system call

starting xv6:

RISC-V computer powers on
-> initializes itself
-> runs a boot loader(stored in read-only memory(ROM))
-> boot loader loads xv6 kernel into memory
the kernel loaded into memory at physical address 0x80000000, because the address range 0x0:0x80000000 contains I/O devices.
-> CPU executes xv6 starting at _entry(kernel/entry.S:7)(in machine mode and paging hardware disable).
paging hardware disable : virtual addresses map directly to physical addresses.

_entry

_entry:    # set up a stack for C.    # stack0 is declared in start.c(kernel/start.c:11),    # with a 4096-byte stack per CPU.    # sp = stack0 + (hartid * 4096)    la sp, stack0    li a0, 1024*4    # csr is control and state register,csrr is read somethings to csr    # hartid(Hart ID register) was stored id of currently hart(hardware thread)    # hardware(CPU's core) is independent to software,     # each core has a stack with a space of 4096 bytes in multi-core processors    csrr a1, mhartid    # the core'id is starting from 0,so hartid need add 1 before *4096,    # after stack0 added hartid+1*4096, the sp is the top of the stack,    # because the stack on risc-v grows down.    addi a1, a1, 1    mul a0, a0, a1    add sp, sp, a0    # jump to C-code function start() in start.c(kernel/start.c:15)    call start

start()

performs some configuration that is only allowed in machine mode, the last, it programs the clock chip to generate timer.
then switches to supervisor mode by calling instruction mret. and start delegates all interrupts and exceptions to supervisor mode.
with this housekeeping out of the way, the program counter change to main(kernel/main.c:11).

mret

â€œmachine-mode returnâ€, most often used to return from previous call and from currently privilege mode to previous mode. mret do these depend on register â€œ*mstatusâ€, â€œ*mepcâ€ and â€œsatpâ€œ. (start isnâ€™t returning from such a call, but sets things up as if it were.)

mstatus register: store previous privilege mode. (start writes supervisor)mepc register: save return address(start writes main's address)satp register: page-table register, it has a field of mode that writed 0 can disable virtual address translation.(start set 0)

the first process:

main() #kernel

main initializes several devices and subsystems.
main creates the first process by calling userinit(kernel/proc.c:233).

the first process #kernel

the first process executes a small program (written in RISC-V assembly) which makes the first system call initcode(user/initcode.S:3) in xv6.

system call:

initcode #user space

it loads the number for the exec system call (SYS_EXEC (kernel/syscall.h:8)) into register a7, and then calls ecall to re-enter the kernel.

ecall #kernel

ecall use the number in a7(now was stored the number of exec) in syscall(kernel/syscall.c:132) to call the desired system call.

system call table #kernel

it(kernel/syscall.c:107) maps SYS_EXEC to the function sys_exec

sys_exec #kernel

exec replaces the memory and register of the current process with /init(user/init.c:15).

/init #user space

init creates a new console device file (if need) and then open it as file descriptors 0, 1, and 2.
Then it starts a shell on the console.
The system is up.

2.7 Security Model
